NewsLine.NewsLineText: SPORT-GOLF-RYDER-PREVIEW:Golf-Ryder-Europe and U.S. set to resume rivalry after long wait

body.p: SUTTON COLDFIELD, England, Sept 23 (Reuters) - One of the fiercest rivalries and great occasions in global sport resumes this week when Europe host the United States in the Ryder Cup team competition at The Belfry after a protracted three-year break.
The 34th edition of the biennial contest should have been held at the same venue last year, but the event was postponed for 12 months following the September 11 attacks on the U.S.
At the time, though, it was agreed by the PGA of America and the European Ryder Cup board that the same 12-man teams would line up at The Belfry one year on.
Ever since, players on both sides have been forced to wait it out with their uniforms safely tucked away in cupboards.

But, all the while, they have focused on their individual playing schedules while their form has been subject to close Ryder Cup scrutiny, many of them feeling as though they have had to keep on justifying their initial selection.
Hardly surprisingly, several players have struggled for consistency for much of this year and very few of the European team are performing better now than 12 months ago.

Main concerns for European captain Sam Torrance before the Ryder Cup starts on Friday morning with the fourball matches are Sweden's Pierre Fulke, Englishman Lee Westwood, Irishman Paul McGinley, Phillip Price of Wales and Ulsterman Darren Clarke, who finished 63rd out of 64 in the WGC-American Express Championship on Sunday.

To a lesser extent, the U.S. also have their own worries and team captain Curtis Strange will hope that Ryder Cup veteran Hal Sutton and debutant Stewart Cink can rediscover some form at The Belfry after respective seasons of struggle.
Both Sutton and Cink failed to qualify for the elite World Golf Championship (WGC) field in Ireland last week.

The Ryder Cup, though, is a matchplay event and players on both sides readily accept it is possible for someone who has struggled in individual strokeplay tournaments to rise to the occasion in a team atmosphere.
'EVERYTHING CHANGES'

"The atmosphere and the energy and everything inside of you changes for a Ryder Cup," said Spaniard Sergio Garcia, after giving his European colleagues a boost for The Belfry with a course-record 10-under-par 62 in the final round in Ireland on Sunday.
"And I think that's the case even for players who are not playing that great. In the Ryder Cup, you try extra hard to play well. It shows on every Ryder Cup."
U.S. captain Strange readily accepts that some players will go into a Ryder Cup desperately searching for form.
"When has the Ryder Cup ever been played with 24 of the best players at that time?" he asked. "Probably never. But will it take away from the matches? Absolutely not."

As far as both collective form and team quality are concerned, the U.S. will go into this week's Ryder Cup as firm favourites to retain the title they won by 14-1/2 points to 13-1/2 at Brookline in 1999.
Their line-up includes seven winners of at least one major tournament while Europe have only one in twice U.S. Masters champion Bernhard Langer.
The U.S. team also includes five players in the world's current top 10, Europe only have two -- in fifth-ranked Garcia and number nine Padraig Harrington.

In world number one Tiger Woods, the Americans have a player who is close to his very best form, having clinched his sixth title of the year on Sunday with a clinical one-shot victory in the American Express Championship and a remarkable 72-hole total of 25 under par.

It is worth remembering, though, that Woods has not thrived in the Ryder Cup, winning only 3-1/2 points in 10 games since making his debut at Valderrama in 1997. The Ryder Cup, as Woods himself put it last week, is "a different animal".
NO DIFFERENCE
"On paper, as we've seen in the Ryder Cup, it doesn't make any difference at all how guys are playing coming in," added Strange.
"It's who's motivated, who can adjust to the long week, the social atmosphere as well as the golf. I don't care who it is but, when the Ryder Cup begins, anything is possible."

The biennial clash between the top 12 professionals in Europe and the United States could hardly have been closer fought since 1981. Europe and the U.S. have won four matches apiece with one encounter -- at The Belfry in 1989 -- tied.
In those nine contests, only one was decided by a margin of more than two points and the event has often transcended golf to become sporting theatre of the most dramatic kind.

"I don't see a blow-out (a one-sided result) this week," said left-hander Mickelson, who gave himself a confidence boost for The Belfry with a closing round of eight-under-par 64 at Mount Juliet on Sunday.
"The format is more conducive to levelling the playing field and, in the past 20 years, it's been pretty obvious that the competition is even on both sides of the Atlantic."

The U.S., who have won 24 Ryder Cups to the seven claimed by Britain or (since 1979) Europe, produced a dramatic last-day fightback at Brookline in 1999, winning eight of the 12 singles matches to regain the cup by 14-1/2 points to 13-1/2.
They may, once again, be firm favourites for this week's showdown but, if the last 20 years are anything to go by, expect a nail-biting result -- whoever wins.
